basics.name: David N. Palacio
basics.label: Ph.D(c) Computer Science
basics.summary: Ph.D. candidate specializing in deep learning and software engineering, with expertise in applying causal inference techniques to interpret large language models (LLMs), aimed at automating software maintenance tasks. Eager to leverage these skills as a Research Scientist focused on AI development, trustworthiness, alignment, and explainability.

work.name: Microsoft
work.summary: Published a patent for an innovative debugging tool designed to provide recourse to practitioners in explaining deep generative models trained on code as data. Worked in collaboration with four Microsoft Senior research scientists.

work.name: Cisco Systems
work.summary: Investigated an information theory approach for interpreting and evaluating software retrieval techniques.

work.name: KSMTI
work.summary: Engineered reactive and functional programming architectures for enabling fast development of any type of marketplace business.

research.summary: Worked at the SEMERU Research Group as a Lead Researcher under the advisement of Professor Denys Poshyvanyk Ph.D, published 12 research papers across various top‑tier Software Engineering conferences and journals.
Developed a hybrid adaptive evolutionary algorithm in Java/Scala to detect and recommend feasible software refactorings.

awards.title: Indian Government Scholarship in Noida, India

certificates.name: Distributed Machine Learning with Apache  Spark

publications.name: Toward a Theory of Causation for Interpreting Neural Code Models
publications.summary: It concerned a causal theory for understanding LLMs for code.

publications.name: Debugging Tool for Code Generation Neural Language Models
publications.summary: A debugging tool identifies the smallest subset of an input sequence or rationales that influenced a neural language model.

publications.name: Which Syntactic Capabilities Are Statistically Learned by Masked Language Models for Code?
publications.summary: Limitations of evaluating Masked Language Models (MLMs) in code completion tasks.
